articles.headline: Justices, 5-4, Reject Corporate Spending Limit
articles.snippet: Overruling two precedents, a divided Supreme Court ruled that the government may not ban political spending by corporations in candidate elections.
articles.abstract: Overruling two precedents, a divided Supreme Court ruled that the government may not ban political spending by corporations in candidate elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Overruling two important precedents about the First Amendment rights of corporations, a bitterly divided Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that the government may not ban political spending by corporations in candidate elections.

articles.headline: Obama’s Move to Limit ‘Reckless Risks’ Has Skeptics
articles.snippet: The president on Thursday proposed legislation to limit the scope and size of large financial institutions.
articles.abstract: The president on Thursday proposed legislation to limit the scope and size of large financial institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama wants to cut down to size those too-big-to-fail banks. But his vow on Thursday to rewrite the rules of Wall Street left many questions unanswered, including the big one: Would this really prevent another financial crisis?
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Basking in Islands of Legalisms
articles.snippet: He has been accused of securities fraud and ordered to repay money. But millions are tied up in a trust in the Cook Islands.
articles.abstract: He has been accused of securities fraud and ordered to repay money. But millions are tied up in a trust in the Cook Islands.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Cook Islands have a smaller population  about 20,000  than one apartment complex in Manhattan, and an economy with little to offer except tourism and pearl exports. The country contracts out its national defense to New Zealand, which is four hours away by plane.

articles.headline: With Populist Stance, Obama Takes On Banks
articles.snippet: A call for new limits on bank size and risk reflects a shift in the administration’s focus and in the political climate.
articles.abstract: A call for new limits on bank size and risk reflects a shift in the administration’s focus and in the political climate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The tougher approach to financial regulation that President Obama outlined on Thursday reflected a changed political climate, the rebound in big banks’ fortunes after their taxpayer bailout and a shift in power within the administration away from those who had been seen as most sympathetic to Wall Street.

articles.headline: If Bills Fail, a Quandary for Insurers
articles.snippet: The health care legislation that could now die in the Senate might have helped the insurance industry over the long term.
articles.abstract: The health care legislation that could now die in the Senate might have helped the insurance industry over the long term.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the possible collapse of the Congressional health care effort, health insurers might seem to have reason to celebrate. The legislation threatened to remake much of their business, with the prospect of burdensome government regulation and less profit from selling coverage to individuals and small businesses.

articles.headline: Lobbyists Get Potent Weapon in Campaign Ruling
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court decision will increase the power of interest groups at the expense of candidates and parties.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court decision will increase the power of interest groups at the expense of candidates and parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court has handed lobbyists a new weapon. A lobbyist can now tell any elected official: if you vote wrong, my company, labor union or interest group will spend unlimited sums explicitly advertising against your re-election.

articles.headline: Treasury Weighs Fixes to Foreclosures Program
articles.snippet: The effort to revamp the Making Home Affordable program comes amid growing pressure to do less for banks and more for households.
articles.abstract: The effort to revamp the Making Home Affordable program comes amid growing pressure to do less for banks and more for households.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration plans next week to revamp its $75 billion program aimed at sparing homeowners from foreclosure, streamlining the documents required of borrowers seeking lowered payments, according to financial industry executives and others who have met in recent days with Treasury officials.
